etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in Herbert Spencer (1820–1903), philosopher, social theorist, and sociologist. From re- + differentiate

definitions: To cause (cells or tissue) to become specialized again following loss of differentiation. Usually in passive.
Especially of cells or tissue: to become specialized again following a loss of differentiation; to undergo redifferentiation.
To differentiate (a function) that is itself a derivative; to differentiate again or further.
